Berry To Be At Fireside
Following in the footsteps of the
first Fireside Discussion Group,
which met last Thursday at President Bowman's home, another
meeting will be held at Levering
Hall at 4.15 this coming Thursday.
Dean Edward Berry of the College
of Arts and Sciences will speak.
Two sheets, one in Levering Hall,
and the other in the Postoffice, will
be posted. Each is limited to ten
names of people who will definitely
attend. In the future, when two
meetings a week are planned, sheets
will be posted in Levering Hall on
Friday before the meeting. These
will hold notifications of the speakers, the topics, and the time of
the meeting.

Springfield, Mass. - ( ACP) — Assailing educational views of the University of Chicago's Pres. Hutchins as
"counsels of despair," Dr. Earnest M.
Best, new president of Springfield
College, in his inaugural address suggested a frank facing of problems as
they exist.
"President Hutchins of the University of Chicago would purify and simplify education by a retreat into the
narrow intellectualism of scientific research and philosophical speculation
and leave the world to its fate in
'trades associations'," said the former
McGill University psychology professor.
"These proposals are the counsels
of despair. We have much to learn
from the past but in my opinion we
must advance by a frank recognition
of the centrality of vocational and
professional education in modern life.
"The defects of vocational education can be remedied by making sure
that the schools build good men and
good citizens as well as good specialists," concluded Dr. Best.

The February Issue of Human Biology, a quarterly magazine devoted to
records of research in biological fields,
is now on sale. In the current issue
there is an illustrated, complete record on the relationship between menarcheal age and certain measurements
Of physique in girls of the ages nine
to sixteen years. Based on actual
Measurements taken on many thousands of girls of junior and high school
age, certain conclusions are drawn by
Calvin P. Stone and Roger G. Barker
Of the Psychological Laboratory of
Stanford University. These conclusions have to do with the attitudes and
interests of pubescent and non-pubescent girls.
La Mesnarcliere's Poetique (1639)
is the topic of an exhaustive study
and comment by Helen Reese Reese.
Sources of the work by La Mesnardiere and his dramatic theories are
notated. The work is noteworthy as
being the first of its kind on La Mesnardiere, who has received little consideration and less notice in previous
Works of literary criticism.

Committee Ponders
Leveringi Changes

The newly organized committee for
the improvement of Levering Hall
met recently and formulated many
plans. Various arrangements were
considered with regard to making better use of the available space.
At its meeting the group determined that something should be done
immediately about the need for a
room for the "Y" Cabinet. As a result, the room on the left of the
entrance to the dance floor is being
prepared for its use.
The group is planning to have a
game room, with facilities for ping
pong and pool. The Sherwood parlor
is to be given over entirely to the
girls on the campus, both graduate
students and students in the College
for Teachers. A room will also be
retained as a study hall with , a little
greater freedom for conversation than
is possible in the library. The reading
corner may be enlarged and the
amount of literature available increased. No small amount of discussion is concerned with the present
arrangement of the soda fountain and
cafeteria. It is problematical whether
a satisfactory solution can be reached
within a short period of time.
'
The committee will welcome helpful suggestions. Any student wishing
to be of assistance should communicate with members of the comirnitte
or with Miss Diggs at the desk in
Levering Hall.

Surprising a good field, Norman
Baetjer sprinted to victory in the
70 yard A.A.U. dash at the track
and field meet at the Fifth Regiment
Armory Saturday night in the time of
7.2 seconds. In placing first, Baetjer
enabled the Hopkins to tie for the
fourth place in the A.A.U. division
in a field of twenty opponents with
a total of five points.
Baetjer's time of 7.2 seconds
equalled the time made by Hopkins
of Virginia who won the Intercollegiate division of the 70 yard dash. Ted
Graziano, the Hopkins entrant in
that division, placed third in his

Springfield, Mass. - ( ACP) — Assailing educational views of the University of Chicago's Pres. Hutchins as
"counsels of despair," Dr. Earnest M.
Best, new president of Springfield
College, in his inaugural address suggested a frank facing of problems as
they exist.
"President Hutchins of the University of Chicago would purify and simplify education by a retreat into the
narrow intellectualism of scientific research and philosophical speculation
and leave the world to its fate in
'trades associations'," said the former
McGill University psychology professor.
"These proposals are the counsels
of despair. We have much to learn
from the past but in my opinion we
must advance by a frank recognition
of the centrality of vocational and
professional education in modern life.
"The defects of vocational education can be remedied by making sure
that the schools build good men and
good citizens as well as good specialists," concluded Dr. Best.

The February Issue of Human Biology, a quarterly magazine devoted to
records of research in biological fields,
is now on sale. In the current issue
there is an illustrated, complete record on the relationship between menarcheal age and certain measurements
Of physique in girls of the ages nine
to sixteen years. Based on actual
Measurements taken on many thousands of girls of junior and high school
age, certain conclusions are drawn by
Calvin P. Stone and Roger G. Barker
Of the Psychological Laboratory of
Stanford University. These conclusions have to do with the attitudes and
interests of pubescent and non-pubescent girls.
La Mesnarcliere's Poetique (1639)
is the topic of an exhaustive study
and comment by Helen Reese Reese.
Sources of the work by La Mesnardiere and his dramatic theories are
notated. The work is noteworthy as
being the first of its kind on La Mesnardiere, who has received little consideration and less notice in previous
Works of literary criticism.

Committee Ponders
Leveringi Changes

The newly organized committee for
the improvement of Levering Hall
met recently and formulated many
plans. Various arrangements were
considered with regard to making better use of the available space.
At its meeting the group determined that something should be done
immediately about the need for a
room for the "Y" Cabinet. As a result, the room on the left of the
entrance to the dance floor is being
prepared for its use.
The group is planning to have a
game room, with facilities for ping
pong and pool. The Sherwood parlor
is to be given over entirely to the
girls on the campus, both graduate
students and students in the College
for Teachers. A room will also be
retained as a study hall with , a little
greater freedom for conversation than
is possible in the library. The reading
corner may be enlarged and the
amount of literature available increased. No small amount of discussion is concerned with the present
arrangement of the soda fountain and
cafeteria. It is problematical whether
a satisfactory solution can be reached
within a short period of time.
'
The committee will welcome helpful suggestions. Any student wishing
to be of assistance should communicate with members of the comirnitte
or with Miss Diggs at the desk in
Levering Hall.

Surprising a good field, Norman
Baetjer sprinted to victory in the
70 yard A.A.U. dash at the track
and field meet at the Fifth Regiment
Armory Saturday night in the time of
7.2 seconds. In placing first, Baetjer
enabled the Hopkins to tie for the
fourth place in the A.A.U. division
in a field of twenty opponents with
a total of five points.
Baetjer's time of 7.2 seconds
equalled the time made by Hopkins
of Virginia who won the Intercollegiate division of the 70 yard dash. Ted
Graziano, the Hopkins entrant in
that division, placed third in his
heat, and was eliminated in the semi-
